DOC.HEAD: Rubles Worth Cab Ride, Perhaps More, in Nome
DOC.TEXT: Three rubles will buy a cab ride in Nome as part of a fledgling Chamber of Commerce project to let Soviets spend their currency here. Jim Stimpfle of the chamber's Committee for Cooperation, Commerce and Peace said last week the project is a way to give the non-convertible ruble some value in the United States. He said he hopes that eventually acceptance of rubles in Nome will snowball into the ruble becoming officially convertible into dollars at a reasonable rate of exchange. ``It's good will, it's friendship, it's solidarity,'' Stimpfle said. The ruble project grows from the opening of travel between Alaska and the Soviet Far East during the last two years. Stimpfle said there were 85 flights between Nome and the Soviet port town of Provideniya in 1989. During the summer an average of 10 Soviets a week were in Nome, either for a visit or passing through, he said. Most Soviets arrive with $40 from their sponsoring organizations in the Soviet Union, he said. Their government prohibits them from taking rubles from home, but many do so anyway and make black-market swaps for dollars with Alaskans planning trips to Provideniya. Stimpfle said $1 in the Soviet Union here officially brings six rubles. In Nome, under-the-table rates for rubles vary. Under the chamber's plan, businesses are encouraged to establish their own rates of exchange. Checker Cab, which charges $3 for a ride in Nome, has agreed to take Soviet passengers for three rubles, and Stimpfle said at least two other businesses are willing to consider rubles. He's ordered stickers that say, in Russian, ``Rubles Accepted Here'' and will distribute them to participating companies.
